idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 2; Esri ArcCatalog 9.2.4.1420

descript.abstract: World Gazetteer is a point theme representing the locations and proper names for map features around the world. The gazetteer includes attribute and annotation name information from various layers of the Digital Chart of the World. Attribute information includes the name, country category and description of the features.
descript.purpose: World Gazetteer provides a base map layer that may be used to find locations by their proper name anywhere around the world. The categories include airports, coastal features, drainage features, land features, ocean features, islands, political features, and populated places.
descript.supplinf: Largest scale when displaying the data: 1:1,000,000.

Outside the United States- Please direct all inquiries regarding software/data pricing, sales, support, and consulting services to your local Esri Office. This information can be found at http://www.esri.com/about-esri/locations.html.
For other questions or comments, you may contact Esri headquarters by e-mail, telephone, or fax or write to us.

digtinfo.formspec: The SDC file contains the geospatial and attribute data. The SDI file contains the spatial index. The PRJ file contains the coordinate system information (optional). The XML file (*.sdc.xml) contains the metadata describing the data set (optional).

stdorder.ordering: Data & Maps is available only as part of Esri software.

distinfo.techpreq: To use this data requires software that supports SDC files.

citeinfo.title: Digital Chart of the World
citeinfo.origin: Defense Mapping Agency, presently known as National Imagery and Mapping Agency

procstep.procdesc: The following steps were performed by Esri: Extracted the features from the Digital Chart of the World. Restructured attributes for easier feature classifications. Updated attribute values based on political changes and other factors. Created ArcGIS layer file (.lyr). Created ArcView GIS legend file (.avl). Created projection file (.prj). Created spatial indices.

citeinfo.origin: United States Department of State, Bureau of Intelligence and Research
citeinfo.title: Geographic and Global Issues Quarterly

pubinfo.publish: United States Department of State, Bureau of Intelligence and Research

citeinfo.title: The World Factbook 2000; 2002; 2007
citeinfo.othercit: The Factbook has been an annual publication, but selected data and maps are updated periodically online.

procstep.procdesc: The following steps were performed by Esri: Updated FIPS_CNTRY attribute for East Timor and Serbia & Montenegro. Created ArcGIS layer file (.lyr), projection file (.prj), and spatial indices. Converted the data set to SDC.
The following steps were performed by Esri: Updated attribute values for Taiwan. Removed the Paracel and Spratly island groups.
The following steps were performed by Esri: Reduced the attribute widths for CATEGORY and DESCRIPT.

The following steps were performed by Esri: Duplicated the point for the 'Sea of Japan' and renamed the new point 'East Sea'. Moved the 'Sea of Japan' point closer to Japan and moved the 'East Sea' point closer to the Korean peninsula. Changed name from 'Kiev' to 'Kyiv' for the four records related to Kyiv, Ukraine.

The following steps were performed by Esri: Updated the FIPS_CNTRY attribute for all points in Serbia to 'RB' and in Montenegro to 'MJ'. Converted the data set to SDC. Created projection file (.prj), and spatial indices.

horizpa.horizpar:
The horizontal accuracy, at a 90 percent confidence level for circular error, ranges from 1,600 feet to 7,300 feet. These figures are the root sum square of Operational Navigation Chart (ONC)/Jet Navigation Chart (JNC) sheet positional errors plus the additional error introduced by the Digital Chart of the World production process.
Since the features are derived from annotation, they do not correspond with the true location because the latitude and longitude coordinate values were derived from the annotation location rather than the map feature itself. Locations taken from annotation are based on the lower left corner of the first letter. Also, the names associated with fuzzy polygons may occur anywhere in the general area of the feature. For example, the name 'Rocky Mountains' is a point located somewhere in the general area covered by the term Rocky Mountains. Fuzzy polygon names, which appeared on more than one ONC sheet, will occur more than once.

dataqual.logic: The shapefile is converted to SDC (Smart Data Compression) format using tools in ArcGIS. The SDC data set is then imported into a file geodatabase to verify, validate, and if needed repair the geometry. The data set is created directly from a topologically correct ArcInfo coverage.
dataqual.complete: After processing, the data set is checked for drawing display and number of records and file sizes compared with source materials.
